title.narrative: WASH:EARLY YEARS

description.narrative: Mothers newborns and children have equitable access to clean water, improved sanitation and hygiene at health facilities in targeted areas, which contributes to Care And Treatment Of Children Affected By Hiv And Aids, Child Health, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Maternal And Newborn Health, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Micronutrients, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Nutrition â€“ General, Operations Support To Programme Delivery, Pmtct And Infant Male Circumcision, Protect, Care And Support Children And Families Affected By Hiv, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices (Covid), Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: More children, including the most marginalized , are surviving, healthy, well nourished and developing to their full potential in their early years, with focus on the first 1,000 days

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Mothers newborns and children have equitable access to clean water, improved sanitation and hygiene at health facilities intargeted areas

description.narrative: UNICEF’s support to MOHSPP through strengthening the enabling environment and infrastructural interventions for improving access of the population to basic WASH services in the Health Care Facilities (HCFs) contributed to minimizing the risk of WASH-related morbidity and mortality especially among children and vulnerable population groups. Also,health workers at service delivery points and State Service on Sanitary and Epidemiological Surveillance at National, Regional/District levels from target districts were trained on healthcare waste management (HWM).In parallel, essential sanitary and hygiene items such as soap, chlorine, sanitizers, etc. were distributed to affected population as part of emergencies and COVID-19 response. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:20/01/2022
